meta_data.title: Why Would Someone Check Themselves Into a Nazi Concentration Camp?
meta_data.description:
SPONSORED BY:

AUDIBLE

To get a 30-day trial, a free book, and access to the library, go to audible.com/ndq or text “NDQ” to 500500.

The next audiobook to be discussed is The Hobbit by J.R.R. Tolkien. Matt  is choosing this book narrated by Andy Serkis and Destin is choosing the book narrated by Rob Inglis.

I think there's an interesting metaphor here. And I'm gonna screw it up. But as you were talking,

Right out to meet them. There has to be a level of willingness to confront the evil that's within

It ends up being sent back to Europe. The captain of the ship makes a deal with

Outright refused. And so, as we know, if you know anything about the Second World War,

But that's the epistemology episode.
That'd be great. But getting to your point, I understand what you mean because of his lesson

Yeah, so he wrote a few reports. I mean, there were kind of individual pieces of information he

And so he and two other prisoners escape in 1943. And he ends up making his way back to Warsaw,

And so that information is out there. I mean, by 1943, granted, if you were a small town

But the Warsaw uprising was just like the whole city rising up against Nazi oppression. And he

And 1945. Amy Quick sidebar. Yes.
The craziest thing about this conversation and the emotion that it stirs in me is only half of

No, this is important because, okay, so there's a couple stages here. So he participates

Can you imagine being anyone in Poland to receive the order of the white eagle after that?
That's what that means. Good grief.
We could go on and on about this, but it's and this is a whole other podcast episode. But the

They're mostly shocked that other people are not doing it, which just is right. That's what I was

No, Mr. Lutz, you are sadly and sorely mistaken. That is not what any normal person would do.
It is what a normal person would boast about from the comfort of his basement where he records a

I think he was thinking more along the lines of all hell. No, you know, no, you ain't doing that in

That stands out to me. Another thing is there's this book that was written. I don't remember

one more good deed helping one person helping, you know, finding more food for another person.
And that's that's how we did it one day at a time. Selflessness. How do you want to land the
plane here? I mean, it's hard to land the plane here with questions like this because I I'm sitting
here thinking, I think the same thing as you all are thinking is what does this mean for us?
What is learning a story like this? What do people listening to this? You know, what do you do now?
You know, when you when you hear about something like this, I just think it's so important to
learn stories about people like Pulitsky because it's it begins the process or continues the process
for some of us of doing that self reflection of doing a self analysis of asking yourself what
what would I have done? And and I think as I mentioned earlier, a lot of us come to the point of
of saying, I don't know, I might have stood to the side. I might have not have done anything. And it
it really for me ends up being a moral imperative to not only tell stories like this, but to sit down
and think about how I can become the type of person who would have done something like V told
Pulitsky did. I think there's tremendous value in the details of those of those stories.
Because it's one thing for all of us to say, man, I would sure never want to help unload a

take because this didn't happen because one day a bunch of German 20 year old boys woke up

Let's just do it. That's not how this happened. This wasn't a roving gang. This wasn't a silly idea
that happened on a bet between a bunch of teenagers who had too much time on their hands.
This was a complex escalation. It was a trillion to the trillionth power, little amoral decisions

concessions that got made in the minds of people and families. It was a billion little lesser of

some kind of or I should put it this way. None of us are going to pass that test lazily or by default.
A deep dive into understanding not just that we have problems and struggle with depravity,
but how? Why? What does it look like? How does it escalate? What did a good person, good person
in quotes who looks just like me? Same age, same upbringing, same style, same socioeconomic status.
But in the 1930s in Germany, how did that guy go along with this? That's what someone like me
needs to know. How did that get unpacked? And so every one of these little stories is beneficial
in that it helps to paint a more complete picture of how it happened. It's really easy and lazy

difficult is to do the hard work of understanding why? And then to figure out how to articulate
something that is incredibly hot button and delicate in regards to this topic to say,
maybe again, careful, like, I need to tread lightly. I need to tread lightly and how I think
about that person and that person and that group and about myself and about my ideology and about

somebody who I think has bad ideas or is dangerous. If I want to check the billion little decisions

a lot more conscious of the billion little decisions that I'm faced with and make them differently
than whatever got the people who came before us to the place they got to when they did this.
So I need people because I'm not morally sufficient or intelligent or developed enough on my own
without a cautionary tale. I need people like this to come along and tell these stories that reach
across the decades so that I can see the anatomy of what went wrong in the heart of a people and
of individuals and then try to guard myself against making the exact same mistake because I made it
the exact same stuff as the people who made this mistake in the first place. So for me,
the very passionately held value that I assigned to what you have graced us with with this great
conversation, Amy, is it holds up a mirror to my soul and it's all data that I need to add
into the moral equation that I'm running and it helps to understand it in more detail and I
understand it better than I ever understood it. And so I'll try to do things that are responsible
and good and redemptive with the information. That's the way I can honor somebody who gave up so
much to get the word out. Absolutely. Thank you very much, Amy. Thank you. When I asked you to
teach me about V told Puletsky, I had no idea that it would be this good. So I'm grateful. But
this was you, Amy Lutz, is the guardian of memories. I think it's only appropriate that you get the
last word in this. Go ahead. What do you want? You know what, how I actually wanted to end it,
I was looking up this on my phone as you were talking. There's a great quote from George Elliot
that is the title of the movie A Hidden Life in which she says, for the growing good of the world
is partly dependent on unhistoric acts and that things are not so ill with you and me as they
might have been is half owing to the number who lived faithfully a hidden life and rushed in

little moments.
